utterances: It has been known to work and it's been working pretty well for Obama.
I guess we'll find out how well it works tomorrow.
What's a better slogan or a better word?
Have you thought of a better word to campaign on?
Well, it's - it depends on what you mean by better.
The word change does what the politicians want it to do which is, it creates - it has universal appeal because everybody has their own notion of change.
But in the past, you've had slogans that were a little bit more specific, at least.
You know, John F.
Kennedy in 1960 said let's get America moving again.
It's very hard to imagine a politician saying that today because his consultants would be saying, oh, that sounds like activist government.
That sounds like it's too liberal.
Don't say that.
Don't say that.
So even these slogans that, at the time were thought of as extremely vague and airy, today are thought of as way too specific.
We are talking about change and what it means as a political slogan.
What does it mean to you when you hear a candidate talking about change?
Give us a call.
The number is 800-989-8255.
And we're going to take a call now from Erin(ph).
And Erin is in Philadelphia.
Hi, Erin.
Go ahead.
Hi.
I am calling - I really think that - when I hear change from a candidate, I really think that Barack Obama has the right idea.
He really wants to shift the way that things are happening in Washington.
He wants to shift the way that policy is made.

He's talking about talking to different people from nations that maybe we don't agree with, but he's still trying to make that shift from what seems like a culture of fear, a culture of at least talking and working together and compromise.
So you - when you see the word change, when you, you know, are watching TV and Obama is speaking and the word change is right there behind him or in front of him, that has meaning for you?
It's not a hallow or an empty kind of promise to you?
Exactly.

I actually saw him yesterday in Delaware and just the idea that he had about changing the way jobs are in this country and talking about how people can get new jobs as maybe inflating - buildings in the inner city, I think is really, really a big shift from what we've seen in quite a few years.
So, yeah.
Exactly.
It really does inspire, I think, the true meaning of the word change.
All right.
Great.
Thanks for calling, Erin.
Okay.
Thank you.

So it sounds like a - you know, I guess you might say, Tim, that given that the other candidates are sort of beginning to describe themselves as agents of change that that Barack campaign slogan is working.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, I think there is a certain amount of me-tooism(ph) here.
And I agree with the caller when Obama uses the word change, he's talking about a change in the tone of government.
He's talking about an improvement in the quality of ethics in Washington.
He's talking about moral bipartisanship.
And I think that's the basis of his appeal.
The other candidates talk about change and it could mean just about anything.
There was a very funny moment, in fact, in the - in one of the debates, I forget which one.
When Mitt Romney was insisting that he was the candidate of change and John McCain started laughing and he said, well, you and I disagree about a lot of things.
But one thing I will agree with you about is you are the candidate of change.
And it became this sort of wonderful put down of Romney for changing his position.
Mm-hmm.
Mm-hmm.
Wait, do you think - let's look into the future.
Let's say Obama is nominated, which is not necessarily going to happen, but let's say he is.
Would he - do you think he could continue to run on that - with that slogan or would it - did he need to - does he need to get a new slogan going into the general election, let's say.
Well, I don't know.
I mean, it's a good question.

Certainly the part of the change theme that involves improving ethics in Washington, that wouldn't work quite as well against McCain as it might against some others because McCain sponsored the election reform law a few years back and he's associated with a strong commitment to ethics.
So he might need another tack.
On the other hand, if change means removing troops from Iraq, McCain is a strong supporter of the surge and is less likely to support withdrawal from Iraq.
So it might have that resonance for Obama.
Timothy Noah is my guest.
We're talking about the use of the word change as a campaign slogan, as campaign rhetoric.

From Rochester New York.

Hi, I think that the word change is way too general regarding - regardless of which party is saying it.
I feel like when the Democrats are saying it, after a Republican has been in office, they are simply trying to get voters to switch from one party to the other and same with Republicans.

I like to hear very specific goals and directions that they want to take.
Heidi, let me just remind folks that you are listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.

Why are we voters responding to that?
Tim?
Tim Noah?
Well, yes.
I think it's because so many voters are independent these days.
So when your making a pitch…
Right.
…to independence can't - independent voters, you don't know why someone is independent.
He might be dissatisfied with the Democrats because they're too liberal.
He might be feeling they're too conservative.
There's just sort of no way to know.
And as a consequence, you're trying to (unintelligible) a lot of people who have a lot of different motives in choosing a candidate.

Hence, the vagueness.
Yeah, of course.

I absolutely agree.

Thank you.
Also, Tim, I was thinking - I mean, it sort of also goes along with what has been a trend in recent years.
Of everybody from both parties - candidates from both parties in different elections, you know, always try to position themselves as the outsider.
We're not a Washington insider, you know?
That we're coming from the outside and we're going to reform Washington and change Washington.
I mean the two seem - those two concepts, political concepts, seemed to go hand in hand, it seems to me.
Yeah.
It speaks a long standing distaste for Washington and the politics is done here.
